p: To determine whether common SNVs were independently associated with severe influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 disease, a genome wide association study was carried out using a logistics regression model. Figure 2 displayed the Manhattan and quantile–quantile plots of this analysis. Although no genome-wide significant associations were identified from the common SNVs analysis, we tried to seek some potential risk SNVs. Using a less stringent level ( P < 1×10 −4) [ 22], there are 164 SNVs nominally significant associated with severe influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 risk (Table S1). Among them, an intron variant rs4634725 ( P = 3.16 × 10 −5) was the most significant SNV locating on a protein coding gene, that is polypyrimidine tract-binding protein 3 ( PTBP3). Additionally, another 26 nominally significant associated SNVs locating on PTBP3 gene were also identified, and they have a strong linkage relationship, as shown in Fig. S1.
